TextEquiv.Unicode: Annemarie Clarac [aufgrund von Brief an Maillart (welcher genau?), in dem sie von einem Brief schreibt, der sie politisch für die Nazis gefährlich macht, ist anzunehmen, dass der Brief zur Veröffentlichung gedacht war, aber nie veröffentlicht wurde, wovon AS keine Kenntnis hatte]
Letter from Free French Africa
Brazaville, June 1941
Erika dearest,
\p\when I attempted to mail to you a letter and some manuscripts
from San Thome, a couple of weeks ago, I was sure it would be the very last
occasion to reach you for an unknown length of time, and I felt rather
dramatic about it. In Lisbon you are [add above: one is] told by exactly the people who should
know better, that Free French territories and also [add abov: the] Belgian Congo are cut
off from the rest of the world except for some cable and radio service.
It seemed I was to be sent off into darkest Africa, in order to find even¬
tually the disgave battlefield of vaguely known Free French legionnaries,
of our civilisation.\:p\
\p\This sounded romantic, and not too bad, considering that in Europe our
so-called normal life has gone, for good I suppose, – and to replace it, there
is not even a battlefield left where one might fight. Except for the bea¬
ting heart of London and [add above: still] some peaceful waiting spots like Switzerland and
Portugal, there is hardly anything to be found than [add above: but] a sickening atmosphere
of defeat and silent waiting.\:p\
So, even if it should be a dangerous adventure and would mean a fairewell to
what I had been in love with at home, I was determined to find my way into
Africa, – which was, believe me, not an easy job.I got a visa for [add above: the] Belgian Congo,
and after four weeks' waiting in Lissabon a place on a Portuguese boat which
I had ordered and payed for three months age [add above: before]. On bord, nobody seemed to know
which parts of French Africa were still held by Vichy and which were incor¬
had
porated into free France. If the British would [add above: had] not have kindly prevented me
from running into the open arms of Vichy functionnaries and their Nazi
tutors, I might have followed the advice of a former French officer eager to
join the De Gaule forces, and attempted to tramp my way through from Free¬
town (Sierra Leone) into Tshad. And I owe it entirely to the determined
navy [add above: naval] officers of the free French port P. who took matters in hand for me, that
I found myself one morning in Free French Africa, at a breakfast table in the
officers' quarters, dressed up in khaki, and ready to get started for Brazza'-
ville.
\p\Since [add above: then], I found out that matters in this part of the world are less romantic
than what I had thought, but also of far greater interest. [add above: As you know] I happened to be in
Kaboul when the war started, and gradually saw [add above: consecutively] the Russian Turkestan border,
Indias' North West Frontier, Bombay, the Red Sea and Suez, – had some glimpses of
Europe between Genova, Switzerland, Unoccupied France, Madrid, and Lisbon, spent
some ten months in the U.S., saw Europe again, – warstricken, increasingly hungry
and impoverished. But never did I feel beeing so close to events, so positive¬
ly involved in the forthcoming tragical battle as here in the territory
of the Free French Government.\:p\
\p\Brazaville is the capital of Equitorial Africa, and the residence of the
Governor General Larminat and of General De Gaulle himself, – who, in fact,
has hardly ever [add above: has] a chance to get here. You can call Belgian Leopoldville
at the other side of the Congo river a town, if you like, – it has shops,
bars, dancings [add above: Hotels], some asphalt streets and monuments, many export and import
firms, [add above: a great] many new shiny cars, and its 10 000 [add above: 3500 white] civilians keep up a money making
bourgeois existence. But Brazzaville is, for the time beeing, a garrison,
runned by military authorities, up to its airport and its powerful radio
station, and down to its few little tailors cutting khaki uniforms, and to
its few little "cafe-restaurants" where you rarely see a civilian.\:p\
Crossing the Congo in a motor boat back and forth between the two
places, you get a strong impression of how these French and Belgian
Westafrican territories develop within a scheme of common interests,
keeping up the fight for a common future. Nobody on either side even
visualizes the possibility of a German victory, and the very idea of
future is identified with the victory of the common cause. Both regio
colonies are gut off from their "motherland", but the Vichy government
and the German occupation abroad are looked at as mere accidents of
lost battles. Not yet touched by actual warfare, both Congos have a large
number of their men on the African battlefield, the French with the
De Gaulle forces, the Belgians mainly in Abessynia. While the mother
countries go through the agony of defeat, the colonies are developping
into greater economical strength, independance, and self confidence. I
would not be surprised if the war would help here to prepare the United
States of Africa. The two Capitals where I live now, are by no means isola¬
ted provincial jungle places, but growing centre of traffic and commu¬
nication. The African continent is gigantic, but dinstances are taken less
into account than even in America. I saw a few days ago two planes arri¬
ving from South Africa loaded with 25 young aviators. They had been given
a few hours' notice, and were bound for an unknown destination, – we had the
guess between Tchad, Kairo or Syria. The Governor of Kenya arrived here for
an official visit, the nephew of the Negus past unofficially on his way
from London to Abessynia. One of my French friends from Afghanistan who
had joined the De Gaulle forces, left Brazza a week ago for Delhi, another
just left for New York. I wonder sometimes in what direction and for which
destination I might leave one day, ... but than, I only have just arrived.
And we might within short time emissions for Germany from our RADIO
BRAZZAVILLE
And within very short time we might start German emmissions from the
RADIO BRAZZAVILLE, – you know from your work you did last year in
London how important this weapon might become! – Emissions for Canada
and the U.S. are already working, – we have to do them at 3 A.M.and 3.34[add on side: 5]
A.M. in order to let you have a reasonable hour to listen in. Nazi
stations try hard to disturb our emmissions, but we work harder to
fight them.
\p\I shall write you again, with the next mail, – as I
am sure they won't be able to stop U.S. boats from reaching the
African coasts! — With all my love, as ever,\:p\
your
Annemarie
